title: Limits of Consensual Decision.” Perhaps the limiting case of realworld pathologies generated by decision rules that privilege the status quo was the liberum veto, in place in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth from the mid-sixteenth to the late eighteenth century. Any member of the Sejm could nullify all legislation passed in the current session by yelling Nie pozwalam! (literally: “I do not allow!”). Conceived as a way to limit royal power, it rendered the Sejm hostage to conservative opponents of change, whom foreign powers often bribed to cast vetoes.
